title: Rasmus Frigaard Lemvig
text: This website contains more or less all you need to know about me. More things to come. Feel free to explore!

title: Rasmus Frigaard Lemvig
text:
Who am I?
I am an actuarial mathematics student at the University of Copenhagen with a broad range of academic interests. These include (but are not limited to) probability theory, insurance, statistics, algebraic geometry and number theory. I also like to teach mathematics among other things.

title: Work experience
text:
Freelance Tutor at GoTutor
I mostly taught mathematics, but occasionally also other subjects (2019 - 2020).


Mathematics Tutor
I have worked as a self-employed tutor for several students (September 2021 - present).

title: About me
text: My interests evolve around probability theory and statistics. My statistical interests are very broad, and I like both the theoretical and practical aspects of the field. In probability theory, I like everything involving stochastic processes. As for insurance, I am not yet ready to choose my direction, but I particularly like working with the mathematics of non-life insurance.

title: About me
text:
Other interests
I love reading, especially science fiction (Arthur C. Clarke, Isaac Asimov and Frank Herbert are among my favorites) and fantasy (Narnia and The Lord of The Rings especially). I am also learning German.
As for interests not involving reading, I like to run, preferably around three times a week. Teaching mathematics is also a hobby of mine.
In regards to music, I like many different genres. I am fond of rock, metal (especially power metal) and synthwave. Most popular music from the 50s to the 90s is also a hit.

title: Projects and notes
text: In this tab is a collection of all projects, I find relevant to share.

title: Projects and notes
text:
(First) Bachelor’s thesis
I wrote my first bachelor project in cubic and quartic reciprocity with perspectives to class field theory. My supervisor was Ian Kiming. I first present the necessary machinery needed to give elementary (but somewhat tedious) proofs of the two main theorems, namely Cubic Reciprocity and Quartic Reciprocity. Afterwards, I take a dive into Kummer theory and class field theory in order to obtain a more high level proof of cubic reciprocity. I also spent some time writing and implementing algorithms to compute the cubic and quartic residue symbols in C++. The code is found in the following repositories:

Gaussian integers
Eisenstein integers

Note that in order to compile the code, you need the GMP library. For many, it is likely easier to rewrite the essential algorithms in another language.
A revised version of the complete project can be found here. In the revised version, a few errors and typos have been corrected. The last section on class field theory likely has some errors remaining.

title: Volunteer work
text: University of Copenhagen, Department of Mathematical Sciences. We read all course and project evaluations and determine a proper categorization from these.

title: Volunteer work
section: Danish Youth Association of Science/Ungdommens Naturvidenskabelige Forening (UNF)
text:
Danish Youth Association of Science/Ungdommens Naturvidenskabelige Forening (UNF)
I have done all sorts of work for UNF through the years. A brief overview is in my CV. Below follows a more comprehensive description. I started as a volunteer in 2016, and I am still active. A list of projects, I have been involved in, is below. Note that all attached material is in Danish.

UNF Science Weekend/Naturfagsweekend
Science Weekend is a weekend camp for 7th - 9th graders. The project started small in 2019 (under the name Masterclass) where we had about 20 participants and just as many volunteers. The year after in 2020, the camp had grown to 65 participants and five subjects (from four the year before). Thankfully, the camp took place right before the COVID-19 lockdowns. Thanks to an extraordinary funding, we even held the camp another time in 2020, namely in the summer holidays (with restrictions of course). The following year the camp took place twice, again with 65 participants and a new name, Science Weekend. In 2022, we scaled up further to 85 participants and more than 30 volunteers along with six subjects, and again the camp was held twice. This story will repeat itself in 2023 when the camp is held for the second time at some point in the autumn.
My role in the camp has evolved as follows:

2019: Teacher in chemistry.
2020: Teacher in mathematics (subject: graph theory) and assistant coordinator.
2021: Coordinator and teacher in mathematics (subject: number theory).
2022: Coordinator and teacher in mathematics (subject: graph theory version 2).
2023: Coordinator and teacher in mathematics (subject: set theory and probability theory).

For those interested, the material from the camps are below:

2019 Material
2020 Material (first camp)
2020 Material (second camp, minor changes and corrections)
2021 Material
2022 Material
2023 Material



UNF Mathematics Camp
UNF Mathematics Camp has been held since 2007 and is but one of many UNF summer camps. In fact, a (Danish) Wikipedia article is dedicated to keeping track of them. My role in the project is as follows:

2020 (cancelled due to COVID-19): Assistant teacher.
2021: Assistant teacher.
2022: Teacher (subject: probability theory).
2023: Teacher (subject: applied linear algebra)

I took part in writing the material in 2022 and 2023. The material for the 2022 camp is here. The material for the 2023 camp is here.


Lectures
I have helped as a volunteer in many evening lectures in UNF. I have also arranged a number of lectures in mathematics.


Workshops
I have taught several workshops in mathematics. A list is below:

Differential calculus: Material, presentation
Integral calculus: Material, presentation
Differential equations: Material, presentation
Linear algebra: Material, presentation
Series and sequences: Material, presentation
Number theory: Material, presentation
Graph theory: Material, presentation
Vectors and parametrized curves: Material, presentation



Evenings of Natural Science Education
From May to September 2022, I took part in teaching young Ukrainian refugees in Copenhagen. I also did some of the administrative work.


Miscellaneous
I had the role of secretary in the local branch UNF Copenhagen from July 2020 to March 2021. I was night watchman at Chemistry Camp 2019 and I will fill this role again at Computer Science Camp 2023.

title: Projects and notes
section: Lecture notes in Stochastic Processes in Non-Life Insurance
text:
Lecture notes in Stochastic Processes in Non-Life Insurance
I wrote lecture notes for the course Stochastic Processes in Non-Life Insurance (abbreviated SkadeStok) during my 6th year. A first draft is here.
